But I wouldn't have known about that without being in the parent groups on FB for schools and district. As much as I would love to leave FB, this is the place to be for a lot of local information.

How do you, in your communities, find out where to go for news? How do you find out who the leaders are? Who the organizers are? There are some really great people working on the bussing situation here, for instance, that I was just tweeting about. Dedicated parents working hard.

the worry that now so many resources and communities that were public-facing are moving to discords and thus private and ephemeral - and yes! it's an issue! - but it's been a particularly chilling one with the death of local news, because there just isn't much alternative.

Without local news, without understanding what's happening in our towns and states, I don't know how we bring about change. 

Local events and news are now so often siloed to closed spaces. I've seen a lot of concern about this with the internet, with discord-

No child should be left outside in freezing temperatures for an extra 20-50 minutes, but it happened so many times this year it stopped being shocking. Kids are not dressed or prepared for that. 

But is that here? nope
Not even a whiff of it.

This is what local news should be for: reporting on what's happening in a community. This isn't reporting on what's happening. This is reporting on what happened a year ago with no context or connection to the community and current events, and that is absolutely pointless.

So, good thing we have this app, right?

Only if it works. Only if it shows updates, changes, replacements. And too often, it hasn't. The tech is not dependable. Great effort. Love the idea. Not dependable. Neither is Dean.

The reality here in Grand Rapids is that @deantrans has routinely left kids standing out in the snow and in freezing temperatures. We've had to drop everything and retrieve our child so many times. Kids abandoned at transfer positions. Parents terrified bc bus is an hour late-

But here's the real kicker. This story mentions how convenient it is to know when the bus is actually close, to keep kids safe and warm - the article even mentions kids with special needs, just for the ol' heartstrings - but that isn't the reality.

Is it a great idea? Yes! And this would have been a great story in, oh, August (note that they picture they used was in fact from August!). But it's MARCH and we just had a significant multi-day outage with this app. As in it was not working at all, for days.

Here's the state of local news: a puff piece about a new app!
The reality: It's been in use all year, but "use" is generous and they clearly talked to no families, nor checked any of the parent groups reporting on app issues. The app is riddled with problems and inaccuracies. https://t.co/rJOHerlI5Y

I’m serious here, I’m very curious. Is it because people got so weirdly taken with her so now they have to reject all feelings? I never cared much about her or Theranos until the revelations so I have nothing to react agains.

And FAR be it from me to defend Holmes, who is indeed scum. But that doesn’t mean she was scum at 19. At 19 she was probably just a dumb 19 year old who tried something. 

But if we complicate murderers, why can’t we complicate people who murdered finance?

It is funny (“funny”) to see horrified tales from people upset that The Dropout made them feel sorry for Elizabeth Holmes for a minute when so much of our media is nothing but lionizing and complicating terrible people. We love murderers and thieves! But I guess just sometimes?

But once we're teaching someone's work, we're giving it that much space and air... it feels to me that we should know. Maybe less of a PSA and more of a "here's what I think about this thing, y'all," but tbh it's just not as snappy.

Either way, I think this IS something we navigate frequently, so much so that it might even be invisible to us. I wager we've all be surprised by a citation that shows us we've been thinking of someone wrong all along (middle initial strikes again, etc.).

I'd love to think that should be a practice we standardize with digital syllabi but also we are all very tired and there are at times reasons not to link someone's larger body of work. Such is the problem of standards.
Sometimes it's helpful to add context or links to works anyway. Plenty of authors of all types publish and work under multiple names; I will usually point these out and offer lists to other works.
I'll point to work toward better systems here: https://t.co/tHIYYICHyy

someone asked (it's gone! but it was a good point!) if this can create confusion and yes! it can. But we encounter that all the time - some change names, some use a middle initial and stop eventually, some add one later, etc. Structural inconsistencies are a big issue in general.
I have definitely mistepped here and I am not alone but this is a very small but very critical place where we can all just... do better.

So, a small but general PSA- when you put someone's work on your syllabus, maybe just take a second to make sure you're not deadnaming or otherwise misidentifying them. Understanding someone's basic identity should be core to teaching their work. #AcademicTwitter

Can we think about what model supports "just in time" hiring for universities, for instance? We have to move in that direction if we don't want to plan ahead.

I think there's a lot we can learn from the various ways lean principles have been applied in many industries!

But I am a researcher and educator. Neither of those is about speed - nor should they be. Nor about not planning for the future.

Sometimes we don't need to reinvent the wheel and we can definitely pick things up from one place and apply them in another. 

Sometimes we need something so tailored to the individual situation that applications from elsewhere don't work well. 

I *lean* the latter here.

"...the Human Resources team and colleagues from across campus will be evaluating the GVSU recruitment process during a weeklong event utilizing Lean improvement methodologies."

Okay, but what if we DIDN'T try to apply lean principles to education, of all things?

And what grates is that the best real response to this kind of tomfoolery is to sue with abandon over silly stuff that shows the holes in the language but... in this case... that really just hurts other vulnerable parties. 

Which is, I'm sure, part of the point.

So, listen, I'm not a legal scholar. I'm a regular person who enjoys a close read and a bit of research. I'm sure much much smarter folks are writing much more that I'll probably read later. But I wanted to share my experience of just reading through this because it's horrible.
It's also another "legally, it's not appropriate to be gay or talk about gender as identity" benchmark, and that is a massive problem.

In summary: this just encourages people to sue if there's anything they don't like, without laying out what that really includes or who determines if lines have been crossed. It is amorphous (on purpose) except on potential damages.

Which means, so far as I can tell, all this bill REALLY does is: 
-cost Florida schools $, while pretending it doesn't
-lay out procedures for parents to sue 
-disallows discussion of sexual orientation and gender identity before 4th grade
There's also an amendment that says "actually if parents are really awful, you don't have to report," which means... perhaps that part has no teeth?

The analysis includes references to the FL parents' bill of rights re: informing, etc, but the paragraph about age-appropriate discussions for primary students has only one reference - indicating what grade level that is. No other detail. No nothing. That's just floating alone.

"Any updates to existing guidelines, standards, and frameworks, as well as the adoption of
compliant training, would be accomplished within existing resources." 🤡

From the analysis: "The bill requires the DOE to review and update, as necessary, existing guidelines, standards and frameworks. Additionally, school districts may need to adopt updated training materials based on the DOE review."

But none of that matters, ofc. Additionally, the committee analysis in the House mentions this bill as having no fiscal impact, which... hahahaha, oh man. "Change these training materials! Adjust lessons and materials. Make sure this costs nothing. Also we can sue you." yeah k

Anyway, it's a bad bill. It shouldn't stand up at all; it's vague about everything but its inherent fascism. It's difficult to enact and uphold, it increases burdens on fragile systems, and it's a blatant overstep. I think maybe students aren't the ones who need to study here.
Can someone please show me the actual harm of learning? Because that's what it is that's being attacked: kids learning about the vast wonder of the world and all the ways we can be in it.

But what does it do to a classroom dynamic if teachers are afraid to acknowledge students' lives for fear they will be sued? What does it do to the students? To the teacher? Who's actually being hurt here - a kid who might learn wow, people are different? or the kid being erased?

And how are teachers to navigate that? It's common in that age group for students to explore their families and other personal structures in assignments (whether or not they should is a different convo).

Doubt they care about that, but stretched-thin systems will have to stretch further. Stressed teachers have to figure out what to say if a student mentions their gay families. Because students are "allowed" (lol) to talk about their families.

Primary grade levels per FL DoE seem to be preschool through grade 3. So what happens at grade 4 that magically allows children to discuss this? What's this based on? Who draws the lines? Who's deciding what's developmentally appropriate? Where do we put that labor?

So let's summarize: There's more time spent declaring that parents can sue and what they might get out of it than there is explaining any of these terms or boundaries. The only boundary is "primary grade levels" re: sexual orientation/gender identity.

(No one, because I don't live in Florida, but this isn't limited to FL, either. It's ongoing everywhere. But anyway.) "Who decides" is a very good question here. Let's see if the bill answers it. 

Oh, nope! That's pretty much the end.

So I think it's developmentally appropriate to discuss sexual orientation from the time children can talk - as in it is never inappropriate to me. Nor is it inappropriate to acknowledge how humans exist in the world. Where are my parental rights here?  Who's deciding for me?

"A school district may not encourage classroom discussion about sexual orientation or gender identity in primary grade levels or in a manner that is not age-appropriate or developmentally appropriate for students."

Interesting. I wonder if this will increase or decrease reporting to state agencies. Because while this doesn't change that language, it does mean the writers may have some awareness that their fuckery will have impacts.

So then we move into the meat of the bill and here I will discuss the reporting from earlier. "This paragraph does not limit or alter any obligation of school district personnel to report suspected abuse, abandonment, or neglect, as those terms are defined in s. 39.01."

We can't talk about that "history" and "knowledge of the US Constitution" DeSantis wants without discussing gendered exclusions - unless we just pretend whole swaths of history aren't relevant? Would y'all like to comment on whether or not this is the point?

Also, no discussion of gender identity means not talking about any pioneering women, right? Because in most of those cases that get taught in schools, they are notable first because they are women fighting. And what about voting rights? General rights-issues in history?

Of course, that won't happen, right? (Legally, probably not; they have pocket judges. But per the wording, anything that involves sexual orientation at all - yes, friend straights, that's you, too - is verboten. 
¯\_(ツ)_/¯ Don't look at me. I didn't write it.

I'm not sure these folks understand that "discussion about sexual orientation" could also mean no discussion about any literature or media with even a whiff of romance, yeah? Does this mean no more movies in school at primary grade levels? Most have romantic themes.

"prohibiting a school district from encouraging classroom discussion about sexual orientation or gender identity in primary grade levels or in a specified manner..." So this is meant to prevent discussion of "the gays" and certainly any hint of being trans, but...

Then there's a bit about prohibiting anything that discourages or avoids parental notification and with no bounds on age, that gets sticky very fast, but that's a tangle I'm not attempting this morning.

...I am six lines in and-"...fundamental right of parents to make decisions regarding the upbringing and control of their children in a specified manner"

CONTROL. Well, at least they're up front about it.

Good morning. Taking a break from everything I'm supposed to be doing to instead read the FL House "Don't Say Gay" (jfc) bill. Knew all that time in speech and debate would be handy eventually. Liveread: a 🧵

Last week my child was left out again when the windchill was -17. Does it stop when a child suffers lasting injury?
So the parent leaders are in continual contact and really are going above and beyond all the time. The problem is: it's still happening. And it seems likely to keep happening. Until when?

We have an app that is supposed to help us stay notified on buses. Sometimes it works. Often it doesn't. Sometimes the notifications are just "this bus is late and route won't start until after school has already started." Sometimes there's nothing. I got nothing today.

"Warmer" today. 27. My child and others left outside for 42 minutes waiting on a transfer bus. 

These are not one-offs. My child dresses for the cold and has always layered up. Many don't. Some just can't.

And to illustrate how serious this is, last week when it was just above 0F, small kids were left outside (not sure how long) to wait for a late bus, and then arrived home ~2 hours late. Parent of a 5 y/o reported child home after dark, sobbing and starving.

I know this isn’t just us - it was happening in other places around the nation as well. So what do we do? Parents are organized. There’s some amazing folks collecting stories, facilitating communication, spearheading efforts. But it only goes so far because what’s our leverage?

So now that there’s a distressing lack of local news coverage or concern, as all eyes turn to national matters only, what does one do when there is a community problem like the school district and bus company leaving kids in the cold, leaving them with no transport, etc.?

Anyway, I know I am snarky, reactive, etc. I know all my flaws, trust. 

But I truly believe good comes from my inability to shut up. So I encourage you not to shut up, either.

I don't mean we should neglect research or anything, goodness no (ask me about my 2350923 WsIP), but don't be afraid to make your points in other places, too. 

(You could maybe be less combative than I. I dunno, do you.)

Change in academia is glacial. But... maybe not all of it? Twitter is immediate. Podcasts are fast. Articles may be slow, research takes time, but the discourse drives us, too. 

Tweets won't be saved and they won't change the world, but they can inspire.

I'm thrilled beyond belief when I find I've said something that inspired someone else to do something, to think something, to make a connection, anything. It's awesome. That makes me feel more connected to a scholarly community than anything else. 

And it brings change.

To all early career scholars - go ahead, say the thing. People may tell you you are wrong. Maybe you even ARE wrong. Sometimes people are wrong. That's okay! But maybe we can also inspire people to rethink. Because that's what we can bring: new perspectives. New angles.

I do not love Blackboard (see also: everything; am a hater in general) but I do believe we should all get to see the ways we can maximize our experiences with things we MUST use. The tools should help us; instead they are often obstacles. So if you find something, share!

Anyway, sometimes little things can make a big difference in your user experience - for teachers and students - and we rarely talk about these smaller features in Blackboard. I hope this helps someone!

You can also pop out the navigation panel if you are so inclined. Not something I use very often, but maybe you will. There's a folder icon at the top. Click that and you get a floating menu you can put wherever. https://t.co/dIIIK9pE1f

Different Blackboard releases may have some different labels on things, and of course institutions can set tools and default shells in a variety of ways, but a little poking around can probably get you a calendar and all sorts of other things.

Added items seem to default to the bottom of the list so I always move them up to an order I prefer, but that isn't strictly necessary, just a choice. 

Easily accessible calendars are a great tool for users and it only takes a second to drop 'em there for students.

You have probably used this before to add things like module folders, etc. For this, just add "tool link" and you can add any of the items from the screenshot above. Very convenient. Also useful if your students have a particular website or something they use a lot. https://t.co/7GoNYfHN7O

Instructors: if you want to add a link to any of these items from the nav panel in your class, it's very easy! Just use the plus sign at the top of the panel when in edit mode, like so. https://t.co/iT0UYA6zG7

Some of these of course are already linked from the nav panel, like announcements and email. Instructors can add other links. I often do for group projects, tools, and the aforementioned calendar. Just easier sometimes. https://t.co/XTJR1xOSB4

so here's how to get there: In the navigation panel, as shown here, there is usually a link for "tools." Obviously all BB setups might be different, but if yours has a tool link, it takes you to all sorts of exciting (and terrible) places. https://t.co/pbYZKGulN2

Hey, students using Blackboard - did you know there is a calendar feature? I usually create a direct link in the navigation panel for easy access, but you can get there regardless. One of my students just found the calendar and is excited & I want everyone to be! short 🧵 -

Anyway, it's gonna be another hard semester for a lot of people. 

Dr. Beavers set a high standard of grace and every semester I try to honor and meet it, but this term, I hope we all do.

He didn't have to. He could have pushed "rigor" and "standards" and all the nonsense we hear about what teaching is, but instead he listened, he heard, and he saw me as a person. I stopped being embarrassed at being taught by my jr high friend real quick. Now I'm just grateful.

But I absolutely don't think I would have been if not for (now) Dr. Melvin Beavers, who I don't think is on Twitter, but who just showed up in my mail box, which inspired this bit of nostalgia. I owe him a lot, all because he took the time to meet an angry woman where she was.

Another UALR professor suggested I go to grad school, something I'd never considered. People like me didn't consider it. Who would tell us such a thing? He did, and I researched, and there I went for my MFA. But there I found rhetoric, and I fell in love. Now I'm a professor.

and he gave me the freedom to explore things beyond the syllabus and to work in a way that helped ME. I'm sure it was a huge pain in his ass. I was the huge pain. But I never forgot. I will never forget. I felt seen and heard.

I was (always) a terrible student. Rebellious. Loud. Argumentative. I mean, I'm just myself, but in class. (I don't know how I have any friends; y'all are patient). And I was probably awful there. But he met me where I was - a working writer, but angry and frustrated-

I walked into class to find that the TA was someone I'd gone to junior high school with. I was so embarrassed. I'm surprised I stayed, honestly, but I'm glad I did - he was WONDERFUL. Most of the instructors I had at @UALR were, honestly, but he went above and beyond.

I went back to school years later, because I was freelancing and wanted to finish my degree to get more opportunities (I find that funny now). AP tests meant I didn't have to take comp, but I took the second class in a 2-class set anyway, just to practice.

I dropped out of college in my third semester, though it was immaterial; at that point I'd basically failed out. I wasn't ready socially or emotionally, and now I know I had other untreated mental health issues too, which I'm sure contributed. 

I've got a point, I swear- 🧵

I'm not even trying to doomtweet here. I am just truly blown away by this. I am numb, you know? It feels like something in a movie where you don't want to root for anyone. "Pfft," we'd scoff. "They should have just been testing, that'd solve it."

I can't wish us into being a different people - there was always going to be a fight about masks, vaccines, protocols, all of it, tho the levels are extreme. But tests are material, and that we could have fixed. We are supposed to be fixing. But here are are. Off the charts.

So we leave it to programs who have to scrabble for the tiniest foothold. GoFundMe insurance. We leave it to inconsistent messaging on what to do, when, where, and a lack of tools (tests). 

It is absurd. THIS IS ABSURD.

You know. Like defense systems, maybe. Like the machine of war we build, maintain, and evolve. It is bonkers, just unbelievable, that we have this military, these levels, these systems, so many people... and then look at health care and say no, we can't do it.

We - collectively, Americans categorically - are short term operators. Yearly profits. Until the next election cycle. Etc. But we can't think in terms of "over" for this since we're not moving to end it. That means these systems MUST be created and sustained.

Why is it so hard to just... get tests? To just test? Why are we still lacking that infrastructure? I understand this has been continual crisis mode. Ultimately resources are finite; there's been pivoting; whatever, I am fluent in this language, I get it. BUT-

I think a lot about that "feel good" story. 

It's a feel-bad story, because that one-off program was a fight for money and resources, and it's just... what we should be doing. 

There are so many things we should just... be doing. 

Instead we act as though it is impossible.

As I consider one kid going back to school tomorrow and the other Tuesday, as I talk with someone I love about canceling the too optimistic trip we planned, as I look at the university starting in a week in SOME mode, I don't even know-

A few months ago? what is time - I heard a "feel good" story on NPR about ONE school doing rapid testing regularly to help the kids/community, and how it was a special program (of course), blah blah blah- then there was a lot of focus on explaining to kids and whatever.
I absolutely LOVE IT when pond scum I don't follow and no one retweeted ends up in my timeline for no other reason than the various Twitter machines trying to ramp up that hateclick money.

I really hope it's one folks grapple with.

I think we are going to really need to build those cues into games as they grow even more realistic and immersive from here. But signals that remind us of what isn't real run counter in some ways to the breathtaking brick wall here that looks so real I want to touch it.

And speaking of thematic links - the demonstration of the layers and settings was great, and I love to see that in a demo like this, but also, allowing us to manipulate, test, and separate elements reinforces the UNrealness. Run that car over. It's okay.

The people are still a little awkward, and more in the roaming, but I am okay with it, really. Elder child and I both voiced discomfort at the idea of engaging in violence. Again, I think the Matrix was a good vehicle here. Shoot the agents and watch them dissolve into code.
The wet pavement was particularly beautiful, even when hurtling toward it.

That was a simultaneously horrifying and captivating experience. It was too real, but we weren't, so it was fine; we could test, fall, drop into 3rd person, bash cars together and watch rubbery bumpers skitter across the pavement.

That feeling of being so close to entering felt thematic, you know? 

So we started trying to break it, you know, looking for the best and worst textures, testing things, finding limits, and then we fell. 

From great height toward a realistic-feeling ground.

But on a more serious note- there was a depth and dimension that made it feel real. Not realistic, real- as though the screen was permeable and I was moving through a space. 

The Matrix was a really effective choice for this reveal for that reason-

Happy Food Day, everyone. I wish you a little of our peace, wherever you are.

It is Food Day here now- just a day for eating and being and loving each other. We like food and we like our family- Food Day is a good day. 

I want so much for my children, but fiercely, I want them not to question their memories. I just want them to be pure. Golden.

What I know is that I am growing to cherish just spending this day at home. Watching people come in and out of the kitchen, savoring smells of things they might not even like. Music filling the house. Everyone singing sometimes. Otherwise, quiet. Just us on Food Day.

When I was a kid, this was my favorite holiday and I’m not sure why. Maybe because it was the holiday I had a set routine and no one fought over me. Maybe I loved helping to cook. I don’t know- because so many bad memories are also from this day.

I don’t think it was malicious or anything, btw. I think it’s just one of those things that people don’t think about until it’s brought up, like building in breaks for candidates. So I’m bringing it up. 

Walk more slowly. Take the elevator. It can’t hurt. It can help.

That’s all, really. 

I’m not perfect. I don’t expect anyone else to be. But when I think back to my campus visits, this is all I think of now- that extra layer of pain and how it was completely avoidable.

The walk across campus is nothing now! I know the route, and I can go at whatever pace I feel comfortable at. I know where the sidewalk is weird and where I might trip. But it took a few days to reach comfort, y’know?

And listen- I got a job. I’m happy. But I also cried after my first in-person class because it was by the bathroom where I wept and hurriedly redid my eyeliner before a mtg because the air outside felt like a vise and when we got there I was a rainbow of alarming colors.
Job market is already a terrible, anxious time. We can take small steps (ha) to make it slightly better.

I know that around this time, the other advice threads will start. And I think the process has improved over time. But we can keep doing better! No one should have to plead for oxygen or disclose anything at all that might need them to slow down.

I get this is hard. It’s automatic for you. You walk fast; some people talk fast. It’s your normal! 

So be intentional about it. Decide to build five more minutes in. Walk more slowly. If they are a fast walker, they’ll gradually speed up.
People are probably strangers to your campus. You don’t have to speed walk. That’s a nervous person who is deathly afraid of tripping or doing anything “wrong.” You can let them set the pace.

I spent a lot of time in bathrooms, struggling to catch my breath so I could go into a room to talk to someone. It clearly annoyed some people, this inability of mine to breathe - and when you’ve also got some other quality people dislike (fat, in my case)….

I had to tell people at every place I interviewed that I was asthmatic and plead for elevators. I used my inhaler more during that time than I ever have and went back on other meds as well. Planes, dry air, winter in most places I went… perfect storm for asthma.

Academic market is in full swing now and I would guess places will be going back to in-person visits, so there’s something I’d like to say: 
When you’re dragging candidates around? Slow down. Take the elevator. Default to that, please. A small thread:

I just want to find some ways to talk about my experiences so I can help contribute to discussions around improving mental health care for everyone.
Oh, I do have a final point. There is probably language in here that is not great. I’m sorry. I’m new to even having words to talk about some of my experiences. I’ll learn.
I don't really have a final point. I'm just weary, friends. The days, they are a slog sometimes.

Not "succeed." Not "be productive." Obstacles to existing first. Big ones, small ones, lots of tiny repeated wearing ones. So many obstacles to just being whatever "normal" is. And so solutions are complex.

Well-meaning folks need to hear "If you would just" come out of their mouth and see it as a caution light, if not a stop sign. 

Here's what I wanted to say today: being a person is hard. So many people face enormous barriers when they are just trying to exist. Just exist.

"Your life would be so much better if you just self-regulated!" Friends, I was self-regulating. That was me trying to self-regulate my way into some sense of mental peace. "It's all about self control." You have no idea.

But it's almost impossible to even bring up anything about my body - or in relation, my health, because that always ends up being about my body. 

It's also hard not to think about all the well meaning terrible things people have said over time.

What a day, whew. But to add to this a bit... I WANT to talk about this because I don't want anyone to have the same struggles and we need to talk. But-

I also don't want someone to think "oh, here is a solution to fat." 

It's just a journey. It's mine. It's hard. I'm okay.
@WickedGood It's hard. I'm glad there's light.

@reflectedsparks I get this. I remember the moment things shifted for me and what a tangible change that was. 

Thank you for your kind words of support. 💛💛 I hope we all get to live in some peace.
@katierandall We all have our journeys. 💛💛
@katierandall SAME. I wanna just exist.

@katierandall It’s SO jarring. And I’m so glad now that we didn’t go with a stimulant, because I expect this would have been even harder. That combo of ADHD evening things out + side effects is no joke for everyone tho I bet.
@eve_kenneally @BrianOliu TAKE A TYLENOL

When will I feel like my body does not have to fight a war with the world all day?

Will I ever feel that?

I don't love my body, but I don't hate it either. It is a strong body. It endures. This body holds pain and breaks it. But I have learned now with meds not to fight with my brain every moment. When will I be able to say the same about my body?

I know it's not helpful but it's very hard NOT to ask: what would my life had been if I'd been diagnosed at 10? 13? 15? 20? 

What have I lost?

How can we keep other people from losing time, energy, health, comfort, the ability to live easily in their own bodies?

But all I really want to say is: how many people can't get mental health care that they desperately need? Can't get diagnosed. Can't see anyone. Can't get help. 

What's the toll on the rest of their bodies? Because there is a toll on mine. I'm paying endlessly.

But what I really want to say is... it's impossible to have real conversations about mental health and ties to weight because when you bring up weight, suddenly everyone is an expert and is happy to comment on your body since you opened the door.
If you do at all.

And hilariously, it's kind of an invisible journey I'm on. Because no one saw me forever, and then when they did, I was still just fat - & we get kinda classified as just in the fat box, no nuance. I'm not gonna argue about this. I've been fat for decades. I know how you see us.

I have spent these 9 months trying to learn how to exist in this body. How to eat when I don't feel like I "need" it. How to recalibrate everything around that. I spent decades trying to live without things I needed; now I'm learning to live with them.

I also drink less coffee, way less. I don't "need" the boost anymore to give me a kick in the ass. I just feel... level. It's kind of wondrous. But it's very hard to shake off decades of being. It's been... 9 months? And I'm still not "okay."

I can walk through the grocery store without identifying all the different foods that might boost my mood. Because that's what I was doing. I was self-medicating. I didn't know then. I do now. I see and feel it.

So that's a down. An up is that when I'm not having this experience, I feel great. I can focus. The buzzing in my head is much less. I can sit down and just do tasks. And I can do it all without snacking.

There are ???s about what is causing things - medicine? something else? something mental? and it will take time. She was out of town at one point and I had to see another doctor and got the CONGRATS! on your starvation and inability to eat so whew, yes, grateful for MY doc.

It is in fact incredibly terrifying to try to take a bite of something and have your body just reject food in that moment. I don't eat on campus. I don't know if I'll get sick. I adore my doctor. She is very diligently working through this with me as we try to figure things out.

What's been really shit about this that so often I have said things like yeah, I've lost a good amount of weight but it's BECAUSE I CAN'T EAT and people hear the first part and say GOOD! Congrats! but not the second. 

But being unable to eat is not a congrats situation.

My doctor currently has me doing a food diary at least 3 days per week so we can make sure I'm eating enough - there are signs I may not be and there's an impact on my body. Because there is still a lot of me to be sustained.

I don't mean this as a good thing here, really. On the one hand, it's been fascinating to watch my mental relationship to food change. On the other, I've had many days in which all food makes me sick and many days when I have no desire to eat- to the point of weakness.

There are ups and downs to this. I'll start with a little of both: I was finally diagnosed with ADHD in December, started meds (nonstimulant) and have since lost a significant amount of weight, mostly due to my entire body and self just... changing.

There are some ADHD things I want to talk about with regard to weight and what's been happening with me, but I know that's fraught so I'm giving some time here to mute/ignore/whatever before I continue (on this thread)-

Thousands of others have been pushed out of the workforce for caregiving duties or disability.  That's not changing.

Childcare often cost us more than our rent - even when scaled to income.

I also took a grand total of about ten days of maternity leave. 

Total. With two living births. 

That’s how we live.

I too love an uplifting story of resilience. 

How common are they, though?

I mean, damn, y’all, people can’t afford furniture. They can’t afford FOOD. You think everyone has hundreds or thousands a month for childcare?

Because we demand people give up their bodies and lives for pregnancy, but then we don’t support them. 

We all know this. Some people just ignore it. They’ll point to one example, some 15 year old whose parents helped raise a child while they finished school.

If I hadn’t had access to abortion when I was older, I’d have been similarly stuck. Not by family, but by simple limits. I couldn’t afford a child. Or child care. Id have been at home forever, until I could find low income child care and support. Those programs are strapped.

I relied on many things to get from abused child of drug addicts to first generation grad and professor. 

Abortion was one. 

They want us to rely on bootstraps and then they cut them.

It is an example of rules for thee & not for me. 

Stand up. Even if you don’t personally feel abortion is right for you. Recognize these moves for what they are. 

Because it’s not about morals, no more so than banning masks in schools while the children of governors stay safe.

Abortion kept me safe. NOT having children until I was better able saved my life. 

Abortion saves lives. 
Abortion is health care. 
Abortion is essential. 
Abortion bans are ONLY a tool for oppression. There is no other reason. It is policy from the rich to everyone else.

If I’d not had that abortion, I would have been shackled at home. She would have made me drop out. I know because she told me. She told me pregnancy had ruined my life - and then kicked me out anyway when she found out I had terminated. 

No choices.

She kicked me out and then threatened legal action. She was drunk. A day or two later she found me and yelled at me for not being in the home she kicked me out of. She had forgotten. 

I don’t say this for sympathy. I say this because variations of this are TYPICAL.

I didn’t love with my parents as a child. I was removed from the home and given to my alcoholic snd abusive grandmother. But when I got pregnant, I went to my mother. 

Legally she should not have taken me. I needed custodial consent. Later my grandmother learned.

It wasn’t healthy. My choices were often bad. But in those moments they often felt like my ONLY choices. 

For many people, there are so few choices. Thinking there are choices is a thick protective layer or privilege.

Abortion protected me from ending up like my parents - one in prison and later dead at a young age, the other unemployed, brainwashed, angry. I grew up abused and with untreated ADHD. I wanted love. I wanted dopamine. I wanted to feel normal- sex was an easy supplier.

This is one of those things I told myself I wouldn’t talk about publicly, but that’s silly. I’m not waiting for tenure to speak up, ever. 

Abortion doesn’t destroy. Abortion protects. Abortion protected me from ending up married to a man who later turned abusive.

I have had abortions. Yes, plural. I have two children. I also get pregnant on birth control. My body, this body, seems built for fertility. 

I broke laws at 17 to have an abortion. I didn’t know I was breaking laws. But if I hadn’t, I doubt I would be a professor.

We don't have to drive giant trucks to commute across town. 

We don't have to think of a "lawn" as the only way to make a house pretty. 

We can make a different world. It means letting go of some things, but also finding new, beautiful things.

I'm just someone who'd like to replace her very small yard with anything but shit grass, but I can't, because I don't own this property, because there are laws, because, because, because.

It's demoralizing.

I'm not an expert in this. I'm just someone who is very, very tired. I watched my spouse try to get a job designing sustainable, even net zero houses on the cheap - he's GREAT at it - end up doing something completely different because no one wants it.

We can't fix this with our little actions. I wish we could. But our little actions will help. 

The big action must come from those in power. That's how our system works. Getting them to move is a lot harder. It's one reason we need more focus in the news.

I've seen so many people on my tl lately trying to support people about to go on the market by trading clothes or buying new things. Love it. More of that, too.

This information is sometimes hard to come by. I was just looking this weekend for where to take things here. Let's make it easier! Rhetoricians in particular, I'm looking at you. This is something we can do right now. Research. Make a plan. Enact the plan. We're good at this.

Being more open about mental health struggles can help... with climate action. Organize a textile recycling program at your work. Let's make some one-sheets with info. Rags and soiled things can go HERE; here's how to prep them and where to go. Good clothes can go HERE. Etc.

I had a box of donations that I carried, packed and sealed, from house to house, for TEN YEARS. TEN YEARS. Because I  never got to it and I couldn't just throw it away. Mental impacts on these things are real. But... we can help each other with these things.

I saw a meme the other day that encouraged people who were depressed or had ADHD to go ahead and throw away that back of clothes they were gonna donate. I get this. For someone like me, who will put off things until they are "perfect..."- whew. I GET IT.

Food and fashion are also places where we actually can have an impact, but I'm going to come at this differently: We need to normalize helping each other recycle and we need to normalize sharing and trading clothes.

There's a lot of noise about problems with wind and solar farms or wailing about how ugly they are. It's nonsense. Go be a voice against this. It's important. We can't fix some of this until localities will allow "ugly" fixtures.

Many local laws that attack the unhoused also prevent sustainable or net zero construction. Livable properties must check whatever boxes they've decided to fit "house." This stuff is outdated and needs to go.

Find ONE thing to start, ONE, and fight. Local laws and ordinances and HOA policies, for instance, often restrict things that could really help like... not having a lawn of inch-high grass. Replacing lawns en masse DOES help. We need to not have to fight to do that.

We can weather it. We can even have a comparable world (though I, selfishly, would like a better one). But we have to act. 

So what can you do?

Humans are incredibly adaptable. And with vaccine research and production, we proved we can still come together, globally, and get things done. (Less so with everything else around COVID, but.) It's time to do that with climate action. It's past time. We need action now.
Traditionally the right hustles out for state and local elections. If we want to adapt to our future, it is incredibly important the rest of us do the same.

It is also imperative we elect people who will act, and who will act equitably. It means also doing this at state and local levels so that the people we elect nationally will have fewer obstacles and greater coalition.

Call me an alarmist or a doomsayer. I don't care. The thing is, I think we CAN act. But we have to stop ignoring it. Part of that has to start with the news making this less vague and amorphous and more real.
We need to recalibrate our brains. It's not 30 years from now. For some it's right now. For you it might be in five years. Go look at your five year plan. Now set it on fire. Now it's more accurate.

Rivers and lakes drying up are just meh, whatever. 

We read it, we have a moment of unease, and we move on.

30 years. 

That's generous, though. Most regions won't have 30 years. We have already adjusted to massive wildfires and smoke so heavy people are regularly wearing protective equipment in their houses.
